questions.text: First muscle to be blocked by muscle relaxant:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laryngeal muscles The first muscles to be blocked by muscle relaxants (both depolarizing and nondepolarizing types) are central muscles i.e., muscles of the head and neck (face, jaw, pharynx, larynx), respiratory (except Diaphragm), abdominal muscles, and muscles of the trunk. After the central muscles, muscles of limbs (peripheral muscles) are blocked. Diaphragm is the most resistant muscle to the effect of muscle relaxants The sequence of recovery is the same; way as they go, the way they come i.e., first to recover are central muscles and then limb muscles.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B and D- Limb muscles are blocked after central muscles Option C- Normally 70% of the diaphragm block is considered sufficient which gets blocked with other respiratory muscles. Complete diaphragm block needs high doses of muscle relaxants. To conclude it can be said that for clinical purposes diaphragm goes and comes with other muscles but as an isolated muscle it is the most resistant muscle to be blocked

questions.text: Ideal for perioperative neuromuscular monitoring:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Facial nerve Corrugator supercilli or Orbicularis oculi supplied by facial nerve parallels with laryngeal muscles, therefore, are considered as the ideal muscle for neuromuscular monitoring however due to technical infeasibility they are not used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Due to technical feasibility (enough space to apply electrodes), Adductor pollicis supplied by the ulnar nerve is usually chosen for neuromuscular monitoring Options C and D- Theoretically any nerve can be sued for neuromuscular monitoring however due to technical infeasibility, other nerves including radial and femoral are not used for neuromuscular monitoring

questions.text: ‘Train of four’ is characteristically used in concern with:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers Train of four is the most commonly used modality for neuromuscular monitoring

Highyeild:

Four stimuli, each of 2 Hz frequency are given and the ratio of the 4th to 1st response is recorded.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C, and D- Train of four is related to neuromuscular monitoring it has nothing to do with malignant hyperthermia, closed circuit, or pulse oximetry.

Extraedge:

Options A, C, and D- Train of four is related to neuromuscular monitoring it has nothing to do with malignant hyperthermia, closed circuit, or pulse oximetry. Without muscle relaxants the response height of all 4 responses recorded on the train of four is the same so, the ratio remains 1. With depolarizers, the amplitude of all 4 responses decreases simultaneously, so the ratio remains 1. With non-depolarizers the amplitude of 4th response keeps on decreasing with increased doses so, the ratio decreases. This process is called fading.

questions.text: Which of the following is the neuromuscular blocking agent that has the shortest onset of action?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Succinylcholine Among muscle relaxants, Succinylcholine has the fastest onset (30-40 sec) and short duration of action (<10 minutes) due to its rapid metabolism in plasma by pseudocholinesterase.

Highyeild:

Because of its fast onset and short duration, Suxamethonium is considered an ideal muscle relaxant for intubation however due to its side effects like hyperkalemia and myalgias its use is restricted for difficult airway situations or rapid sequence induction (done for patients having a higher risk of aspiration). Non-depolarizers have slower onset (3-4 min.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Mivacurium has a short duration however like other non-depolarizers its onset is slow (2-3 minutes) Option B- Vecuronium not only have slow onset but longer duration also (20-30 minutes) Option C- Rocuronium is unique among non-depolarizers that its onset is comparatively fast (60-90 sec.) but still slower than succinylcholine.

questions.text: A cesarean section was conducted under general anesthesia. The anesthetist preferred to get the surgery done under repeated doses of depolarizing muscle relaxant (Suxamethonium) but even after the end of surgery patient didn’t show any activity. The neuromuscular monitor showed fading. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dual block A dual block (also called phase II block) is seen in the excessive dose of succinylcholine. Succinylcholine exhibiting fading on the neuromuscular monitor is pathognomonic of phase II block (normally fading is shown by non-depolarizing muscle relaxants). The exact mechanism of the phase II block is not understood.

Highyeild:

Other causes of prolonged block are: Low pseudocholinesterase Atypical pseudocholinesterase

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Pseudocholinesterase, which metabolizes Suxamethonium, is a protein synthesized by the Therefore, in hepatic diseases or any condition associated with hypoproteinemia (like protein-losing enteropathies, uropathies, nephropathies, or chronic debilitating diseases like malignancy) the level of pseudocholinesterase will be low prolonging the block after succinylcholine. However, fading is not seen with low pseudocholinesterase and cannot be the cause of prolonged block in this clinical situation. Option C- Atypical (abnormal) pseudo cholinesterase is a genetic disease, diagnosed by dibucaine number, in which the patient has abnormal (atypical) Pseudocholinesterase which cannot metabolize Suxamethonium thus prolonging the block Option D- Hypokalaemia prolongs the block of non-depolarizers, not depolarizers. Mo reover, there is no fading.

Extraedge:

If a patient does not recover spontaneously in half an hour, then a trial of neostigmine should be given. Normally, neostigmine prolongs the block by inhibiting pseudocholinesterase however by an unknown mechanism it has been found to be beneficial in phase II block.

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about the treatment of prolonged Suxamethonium apnea due to plasma cholinesterase deficiency (after a single dose) except:

options.label: A
options.text: Reversal with incremental doses of neostigmine

options.label: B
options.text: Continue anesthesia and mechanical ventilation till recovery

questions.correct_answer: B. Continue anesthesia and mechanical ventilation till recovery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue anesthesia and mechanical ventilation till recovery The treatment protocol for prolonged apnea after Succinylcholine due to decreased Pseudocholinesterase is: Continuing mechanical ventilation and waiting for spontaneous recovery is the first line of management because it is low Pseudocholinesterase (not absent Pseudocholinesterase), and almost always patients recovers spontaneously. If there are no signs of spontaneous recovery even after a prolonged period then Synthetic preparation of Pseudocholinesterase or fresh frozen plasma should be considered.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- In normal circumstances neostigmine can prolong the block of Suxamethonium by inhibiting pseudocholinesterase Options C and D- There is no role of packed cells or plasmapheresis in the management of low pseudocholinesterase

questions.text: Treatment of choice for atypical pseudocholinesterase:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue IPPV Treatment of abnormal pseudocholinesterase is the same as that of low Pseudocholinesterase i.e., first continue IPPV and wait for spontaneous recovery because the majority of the patients are heterozygotes atypical (have normal as well as an abnormal enzyme) therefore recover spontaneously.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A and B- If spontaneous recovery does not occur, then consider giving fresh frozen plasma or synthetic Pseudocholinesterase. Option D- Giving neostigmine can be detrimental in this situation; by inhibiting normal enzymes it can further prolong the block of Suxamethonium.

questions.text: A 25-year male is to be operated on for exploratory laparotomy. Investigations revealed Hb 9.0 g%, urea 45 mg%, sodium 135 mEq/L, potassium 5.8 mEq/L. The drug which an anesthetist would not like to use is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suxamethonium By causing fasciculations, Suxamethonium can cause hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia is one of the major side effects of Suxamethonium. Therefore, serum potassium > 5.5 mEq/L is an absolute contraindication for the use of Suxamethonium.

Highyeild:

Other C/I of Suxamethonium Head injury: It increases ICT. Glaucoma and eye injuries (increases intraocular pressure). Newborns and infants: They have extra-junctional receptors due to regenerating nerves Up to 2-3 months after trauma. Up to 6 months after the stroke Up to 1 year after burns In these conditions regenerating nerve develops extra-junctional receptors producing significant hyperkalemia with Suxamethonium. Renal failure: If associated with hyperkalemia. Sepsis- sepsis may be associated with acidosis which is associated with hyperkalemia Diagnosed case of atypical Pseudocholinesterase and low Pseudocholinesterase. Muscular Dystrophies: Muscles are hypersensitive to the effect of Suxamethonium

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Propofol has no effect on potassium levels therefore can be safely used in hyperkalemia patients Option C- Non-depolarizers do not increase the levels of potassium therefore, can be safely used. Option D- Opioids again have no effect on potassium levels.

questions.text: A six-year-old boy is scheduled for an examination of the eye under anesthesia. The father informed that for the past six months, the child is developing progressive weakness in both legs. His elder sibling died at the age of 14 years. Which drug would you avoid during the anesthetic management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Succinylcholine The history suggests that the child is suffering from Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy. The use of succinylcholine in these patients can produce life-threatening hyperkalemia, and severe contractions and may even precipitate malignant hyperthermia. In fact, giving Suxamethonium to such patients may turn out to be a fatal event.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- All IV agents including Thiopentone can be used safely in patients suffering from muscular dystrophies however patients may have prolonged apnea. Option C- Nitrous oxide can be safely used in patients suffering from muscular dystrophies Option D- The sensitivity of non-depolarizers also increases in muscular dystrophies but not as much as that of depolarizers. Therefore, non-depolarizers with a short duration of action and no risk of accumulation like mivacurium, atracurium, or cis-atracurium should be preferred. Intermediate-acting like Vecuronium should be avoided but not absolutely contraindicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the side effect of Suxamethonium?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tachycardia Succinylcholine not only acts on nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction but also acts on muscarinic receptors producing bradycardia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Due to muscular fasciculations, Succinylcholine causes myalgia, the incidence of which is quite high (seen in almost half of the cases) Option C- Suxamethonium can increase intracranial tension by causing fasciculations of neck muscles leading to jugular obstruction decreasing the venous return from the Option D- Suxamethonium can increase intraocular pressure by causing fasciculations of ocular muscles. By causing fasciculations of abdominal muscles Suxamethonium can also increase intragastric pressure.

questions.text: True about the Dibucaine number:

options.label: A
options.text: Used to measure the concentration of atypical cholinesterase

options.label: C
options.text: Determines the genetic makeup of individual

questions.correct_answer: C. Determines the genetic makeup of individual
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Determines the genetic makeup of individual Dibucaine no. only tells whether the patient is homozygote or heterozygote atypical. However, this is important information in the management of the patient because heterozygotes atypical (means having normal as well as abnormal enzymes) will recover spontaneously. On the other hand homozygotes atypical (where all enzyme is atypical) will not recover spontaneously and will require either synthetic pseudocholinesterase or fresh frozen plasma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- No test can directly measure the concentration of abnormal enzyme Option B- As dibucaine can inhibit 80% of normal and 20% of the abnormal enzyme, therefore normal dibucaine no. is 80%. In homozygote atypical the no. will be 20%

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about non-depolarizers except:

options.label: B
options.text: Fading on the train of four

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Non-depolarizers block the same site at which acetylcholine acts, preventing acetylcholine to bind to its receptor site, thus producing competitive antagonism. Option B- The most important distinguishing feature between depolarizers and non-depolarizers is that fading on the train of four is exhibited by depolarizers. Option C- The block of non-depolarizers is revered with cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. Neostigmine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase prevents the degradation of acetylcholine making more acetylcholine to be available at the neuromuscular junction to compete with non-depolarizers

Extraedge:

Depolarizers (Suxamethonium) bind to the same receptor site where acetylcholine binds producing persistent depolarization (and hence muscle fasciculation) followed by relaxation due to refractory membrane

questions.text: Shortest-acting non-depolarizer:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mivacurium Overall shortest acting noon depolarizer is Gantacurium but it is still in clinical trials. Among the non-depolarizers available for clinical use Mivacurium is the shortest-acting (10 min.). The overall shortest-acting muscle relaxant is Succinylcholine.

questions.text: A patient with a history of pain in the abdomen for 7 days is to be operated on for laparotomy. On catheterization urine output is only 500 ml in 24 hours. Investigations revealed blood urea 85 mg%. The muscle relaxant of choice will be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cis- atracurium Cis- atracurium and Atracurium have a unique method of metabolism. They are metabolized spontaneously called Hoffman degradation. Since, there is no risk of accumulation, atracurium, and cis-atracurium are the muscle relaxants of choice for hepatic and renal patients.

Highyeild:

Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because it does not release histamine and laudanosine production is 1/5th with cis-atracurium as compared to atracurium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Renal failure may be associated with hyperkalemia therefore Suxamethonium will be contraindicated. Option B- Atracurium can release histamine and can produce laudanosine therefore will be used for renal failure patients in the absence of cis-atracurium Option C- Gallamine is obsolete from clinical practice. Gallamine was significantly excreted by kidneys therefore used to be absolutely contraindicated for renal patients

Extraedge:

Laudanosine is the metabolic product of Atracurium and cis-Atracurium which can cross blood brain-barrier and cause CNS excitation or even convulsions. Gallamine was the only non-depolarizer that could have crossed the placenta and could have caused fetal death. Therefore, used to be contraindicated for pregnancy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old lady with a history of hypersensitivity to neostigmine is posted for elective cesarean section under GA. The best muscle relaxant of choice for this patient should be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atracurium As a general rule, the effect of non-depolarizers must be revered with Neostigmine. However, in a situation where neostigmine is contraindicated (like in this clinical scenario), Atracurium or cis-atracurium should be chosen because they are self-metabolized by Hoffman degradation, avoiding the risk of accumulation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Pancuronium is long-acting and potent carrying the risk of accumulation therefore reversal is a must Option C and D- Rocuronium and Vecuronium are intermediate-acting and also carries the risk of accumulation therefore should be reversed

questions.text: The ideal muscle relaxant used for a neonate undergoing portoenterostomy for biliary atresia is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atracurium The muscle relaxant of choice for neonates is atracurium or cis-atracurium as hepatic and renal functions may not be so well developed in neonates. Moreover, this patient is having biliary atresia so, there is a high possibility of impaired liver functions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Vecuronium should be avoided for two reasons. First, it is metabolized by the Second, 30-40% of vecuronium is excreted through bile therefore in patients with biliary obstruction vecuronium must be avoided. Option C- Pancuronium should be avoided for three reasons. First, it is metabolized by the Second, 10-20% Pancuronium is excreted through bile. Third, it is long acting therefore must be avoided in pediatric patients. Option D- Rocuronium is the derivate of vecuronium with the same pharmacodynamic properties therefore should be avoided in biliary obstruction.

questions.text: A young scooterist met an accident with a crush injury of the hand, foot, and splenic rupture is to be operated by laparotomy. He had taken food 1 hour before. The technique most preferred is:
questions.correct_answer: B. Rapid sequence intubation with rocuronium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rapid sequence intubation with rocuronium The patient has a full stomach therefore rapid sequence induction with the Sellicks maneuver has to be accomplished. Since in rapid sequence bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated, the patient must be intubated as fast as possible. Therefore, muscle relaxants chosen for rapid sequence induction should have a fast onset of action. That’s why Suxamethonium is the muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation however this patient has a crush injury so succinylcholine cannot be used. Rocuronium is unique among non-depolarizers in that it has a fast onset of action (60-90 seconds) therefore, is an excellent alternative to succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Patient with crush injury will have hyperkalemia contraindicating Suxamethonium Option C- Mivacurium has a slow onset of 3-4 minutes like other non- depolarizers therefore cannot be considered for rapid sequence induction Option D- This patient has taken a meal 1 hour before therefore must undergo GA with rapid sequence induction, not conventional GA where the patient is ventilated with a bag and mask before intubation

questions.text: Non-depolarizing muscle blocker used in liver injury:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atracurium Atracurium is metabolized spontaneously by Hoffman degradation so not dependent on hepatic function for metabolism therefore muscle relaxant of choice for hepatic impairment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A and B- Pancuronium and Vecuronium are metabolized by the liver therefore not suitable for patients with liver injury Option D- Suxamethonium is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase which is synthesized in the liver therefore should be avoided in this patient

questions.text: A 66-year-old patient is posted for cardiac bypass surgery for 3 vessel block. On echocardiography, the patient ejection fraction was only 32%. Which of the following muscle relaxant will be most preferred for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vecuronium The major side effect of steroidal compounds is that they are vagolytic, therefore, can cause tachycardia. However, Vecuronium is the most cardiovascular stable, therefore, is the muscle relaxant of choice for cardiac patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Rocuronium in spite of the derivative of vecuronium is not as cardiac stable as vecuronium Option B- Pancuronium is the most cardiac unstable. By releasing nor-adrenaline it can cause significant hypertension and therefore should be avoided for cardiac patients. Option D- Atracurium is benzylisoquinoline and therefore releases histamine which can cause hypotension.

questions.text: False about Rapacuronium:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bronchodilator Rapacuronium has been withdrawn from the market because of the high incidence (9%) of bronchospasm.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Rapacuronium is a derivative of vecuronium. Option B- The onset is similar to rocuronium (60-90 sec) Option C- The duration of action of Rapacuronium is half that of Rocuronium (10-15 minutes).

questions.text: Neostigmine causes reversal of neuromuscular blockade caused by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tubocurare and gallamine Anticholinesterase inhibitors by inhibiting the degradation of acetylcholine increase the concentration of acetylcholine to have competitive antagonism with non-depolarizing muscle relaxant thereby reversing their effect.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A and C- Neostigmine not only inhibit acetylcholinesterase but also Pseudocholinesterase, therefore, can prolong the block of depolarizers (Suxamethonium).

questions.text: Atropine/glycopyrrolate is given along with neostigmine to:

options.label: C
options.text: To decrease the onset of neostigmine

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the duration of neostigmine

questions.correct_answer: B. To prevent muscarinic side effects
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To prevent muscarinic side effects Neostigmine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase prevents the degradation of acetylcholine thus increasing the concentration of acetylcholine to have competitive antagonism with non-depolarizers. This increased acetylcholine also acts on muscarinic receptors producing muscarinic side effects, especially bradycardia. To prevent these side effects anticholinergic like atropine or glycopyrrolate are given along with neostigmine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C, and D - Atropine or glycopyrrolate does not affect the potency, onset, or duration of action of neostigmine

Extraedge:

Glycopyrrolate is preferred over atropine for 2 reasons. Its onset matches with the onset of neostigmine It does not cross the blood-brain barrier therefore no central side effects .

questions.text: Reversal agent of choice for mivacurium:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Edrophonium Edrophonium does not inhibit pseudocholinesterase, therefore the reversal agent of choice for mivacurium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Although mivacurium is rapidly metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase, however, if not absolutely C/I, reversal of non-depolarizers must be done. Option B- Neostigmine is the most commonly used reversal agent but it cannot be used for the reversal of mivacurium because it inhibits plasma pseudocholinesterase and thus can prolong the effect of mivacurium. Option D- Pyridostigmine has also been found to inhibit pseudocholinesterase and hence can prolong the effect of mivacurium. Otherwise, also, pyridostigmine is not preferred because of its long duration of action.

questions.text: A patient was given rocuronium for intubation however unfortunately the anesthetist could not intubate and could not ventilate. The reversal agent in this situation will be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sugammadex Gamma cyclodextrin, available by the brand name Sugammadex is a new reversal agent which directly binds to a muscle relaxant, and forms a complex that is excreted through the kidney.

Highyeild:

The advantages of Sugammadex are: Rapid onset Reversal of deep block Does not require anticholinergic to combat muscarinic side effects as needed with cholinesterase inhibitors. Disadvantages: Expensive Risk of allergic reactions Can only reverse steroidal compounds In the situation mentioned in this scenario, the anesthetist has not been able to ventilate too. Therefore, immediate reversal is needed to save the life of the Sugammadex has a rapid onset and can reverse very deep block therefore can serve as a savior of this patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Neostigmine has a slower onset and cannot reverse deep block, therefore not suitable for this situation Option B- Edrophonium is again a cholinesterase inhibitor, therefore, has a slower onset and cannot reverse deep block. Moreover, edrophonium has a short duration of action so, there is a risk of re-crurization Option C- Pyridostigmine is even having slower onset than neostigmine.

questions.text: For guaranteed recovery from muscle relaxants:

options.label: A
options.text: Patient should be able to hold the tongue depressor tightly between incisors

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Clinical signs give a good idea of recovery however it does not guarantee the recovery. For guaranteed recovery Train of four (TOF) ratio should be > 0.9 (i.e., the twitch height of the fourth response should be at least 90% of the first response) along with clinical signs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A and C- Until recently, being able to lift a head > 5 seconds used to be considered as the best clinical sign for a reversal but now it has been seen that holding the tongue depressor tightly between incisors is a better clinical indicator of reversal than head lift. However, practically it’s very difficult to perform a tongue depressor test on a patient who is not yet fully conscious therefore still, head lift is most often used. Option B- Able to protrude tongue, move limbs, and open eyes are often used as clinical signs to assess recovery however not considered as reliable as the head lift or tongue depressor test.

questions.text: Match the drugs and their reversal agent: Sugammadex 20% lipid Edrophonium L-Cysteine Mivacurium bupivacaine Rocuronium Gantacurium Choose the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d Gamma cyclodextrin (Sugammadex) can only reverse steroidal compounds. Therefore, very useful for reversing rocuronium 20% intralipid can be used as an antidote for bupivacaine toxicity. It binds the active form of bupivacaine As edrophonium does not inhibit pseudocholinesterase, it is the reversal agent of choice for Mivacurium which is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase. Gantacurium is a newer muscle relaxant that is still under investigation. It is short-acting because it is metabolized by cysteine adduction. Therefore, L cysteine can be used to facilitate its metabolism.

questions.text: Regarding myasthenia gravis what is true about sensitivity to curare and Scoline:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased Decreased In myasthenia gravis, there are less receptors for depolarizers to act thereby decreasing sensitivity. Less receptors means less competition for non–depolarizers so they are required in low doses or other words their sensitivity is increased. Less number of receptors means less competition for non-depolarizers, so they are required in less doses i.e., the sensitivity of non-depolarizers is also increased.

questions.text: True about the response to muscle relaxant in tetanus:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased sensitivity Decreased sensitivity In tetanus, burns, hemiplegia/paraplegia, and muscle injuries there are extra junctional receptors making more receptors for Suxamethonium to act producing more hyperkalemia, which means increased sensitivity. More number of receptors means more competition for non-depolarizers so they are required in higher doses, or other words their sensitivity is reduced.

questions.text: A 22-year female who is known case of myasthenia gravis is posted for thymectomy as part of her treatment. The non-depolarized choice would have been:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mivacurium As the sensitivity of non-depolarizers is increased in myasthenia gravis, non-depolarizer chosen should be short-acting and should not have a risk of accumulation. Therefore, Mivacurium which is short-acting, and does not have a risk of accumulation is the most preferred muscle relaxant.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Long-acting non-depolarizers like Pancuronium must not be used in myasthenia patients Option B- Intermediate-acting non-depolarizers like vecuronium or Rocuronium should be avoided in myasthenia patients. Option C- As atracurium and cis-atracurium are metabolized by Hoffman degradation, therefore, do not have a risk of accumulation in case of non-availability of mivacurium, atracurium, and cis-atracurium will be the preferred agents.

questions.text: The neuromuscular block is prolonged in all conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypercalcemia Hypercalcemia can antagonize the effect of muscle relaxants

Highyeild:

The neuromuscular block is prolonged by: Hypokalemia. Hypocalcemia. Hypermagnesemia. Hypothermia. Acidosis. Calcium channel blockers. Hepatic and renal diseases. Local anesthetics. Aminoglycoside antibiotics. Tetracycline. Inhalational agents. The neuromuscular block is antagonized by calcium, phenytoin, and carbamazepine.

questions.text: Muscle relaxant action of vecuronium can be prolonged by: Desflurane Isoflurane Sevoflurane Halothane Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct All of the volatile agents potentiate the action of both depolarizing and non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. Overall maximum potentiation is seen with ether while among the inhalational agents used now a day maximum muscle relaxation property is exhibited by Desflurane.

questions.text: Match the muscle relaxant and their use: Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.correct_answer: C. a-i, b- iii, c-iv, d-ii
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-i, b- iii, c-iv, d-ii Pancuronium by releasing nor-adrenaline can increase blood pressure therefore useful for hypotensive patients. Vecuronium is the most cardiac stable. Mivacurium because of its short action is the agent of choice for daycare surgery. Rocuronium because of its fast onset is the non-depolarizer of choice for intubation.

questions.text: At the end of a balanced anesthesia technique with a nondepolarizing muscle relaxant, a patient recovered spontaneously from the effect of the muscle relaxant without any reversal. Which of the following muscle relaxants would have been possibly used in this patient: Pancuronium Atracurium Cis- atracurium Mivacurium Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, and 4 are correct (Atracurium, Cis- atracurium & Mivacurium) Due to the spontaneous metabolism (Hoffman degradation) of Atracurium, Cis-atracurium patients can recover spontaneously without reversal. Similarly, spontaneous recovery after mivacurium is also possible because it is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in plasma. As Pancuronium is long-acting, it is very difficult to have spontaneous recovery with Pancuronium.

Extraedge:

Although spontaneous recovery is possible after atracurium, cis-atracurium, or mivacurium at the end of surgery however as a rule, the effect of non-depolarizers must be reversed until there is an absolute C/I of the reversal agent because residual paralysis can be life-threatening.

questions.text: Feature of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents: Cause muscle fasciculation Fading Post tetanic facilitation Reversed by neostigmine Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, and 4 are correct (Fading, Post tetanic facilitation & Reversed by neostigmine) Muscle fasciculations are seen with depolarizers. Fading and post-tetanic facilitation on neuromuscular monitoring is exhibited by non-depolarizers. Neostigmine is used to reverse the effect of non-depolarizers while can prolong the effect of depolarizers by inhibiting Pseudocholinesterase

Extraedge:

Post-tetanic potentiation occurs if a stimulus is given after tetanic stimulation. Tetanic stimulation releases acetylcholine which can replace some of the non- depolarizer molecules from receptors producing a response after the stimulus. With depolarizers the membrane remain refractory therefore increased acetylcholine will not able to produce any response. Therefore, post-tetanic facilitation or potentiation is only exhibited by non-depolarizers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true? Diaphragm is the first muscle to be blocked by muscle relaxants Pseudocholinesterase is synthesized in the plasma Incidence of muscle soreness (myalgia) after Suxamethonium is 5% Myasthenia gravis is absolute C/I for Suxamethonium Select the correct answer from the below code:

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above is correct

questions.correct_answer: D. None of the above is correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above is correct Diaphragm is the most resistant to the effect of muscle relaxants Pseudocholinesterase is present in plasma however synthesized in the liver The incidence of myalgia after Suxamethonium is 50% Suxamethonium can be used in myasthenia patients however the effect will be less due to less no. of receptors
